author: Gary
text:
My account was frozen and I was wondering what I could have done, no explanation within the first email.

I sent a email asking for a explanation, I received the following statement “ It appears that you had opened a non-receipt claim on a delivered item“

I had opened a case regarding a non-delivery, the courier claimed to have posted the parcel through my letterbox, the problem being my letterbox is to small. I sent in photos showing the size of the letterbox, which clearly shows any parcel delivery with that method is not possible.

According to Grail, “ In order to unfreeze your account this dispute will need to be closed” so I have to suffer a financial penalty, because the courier claims to have delivered the parcel, when clearly how they described the delivery could not have happened.

The account is frozen because my parcel was not delivered, I am being penalised for disputing this and to have the account unfrozen, I have to take a financial penalty!

Completely unfair decision, with little critical thought or logical explanation.

Grailed username - garyharding21 

Your argument is completely ridiculous, is got nothing to do with the size of the letterbox, but the honesty of the couriers statement about the delivery. If something goes wrong with a delivery you should investigate that matter, not hide behind your policies which are deeply floored.

The issue is; the delivery was made, but that statement is a lie, because the letterbox is to small for that delivery. So just saying the delivery was made is ridiculous, because I have not received the parcel. You should be investigating this matter, rather than penalising me.

Freezing my account because I have made a claim seems rather counterintuitive, I have not received the parcel, I have lost financially on this matter and my account is frozen, what have I actually done wrong!

I have been told the only way the account will be unfrozen, is to close the dispute. So I have to take a financial penalty because the item I paid for, I have not received.

It’s an absolute disgrace, your conduct is ethically 
unlawful, I have paid for a item, I have not received, but I am being punished.

The conduct of the courier company is not even looked at, utter shambles.

The courier is myhermes, which has quite a poor reputation when it comes to delivery.

Follow up


Your conflating the two issues, this issue has nothing to do with the buyer, it’s the couriers honesty regarding this delivery.

So I am not making a malicious claim, I am disputing the delivery of this parcel, that’s the issue. 

You are hiding behind you policies, you should be more willing to engage about this lost parcel.

Which clearly you have no interest in and my financial loss. The point should be, was the delivery successful, if I have not received the parcel, then clearly it was unsuccessful. 

Just stating the delivery was made is unfair, because your taking the word of the courier, rather than looking at the evidence.

If the letter box is to small, clearly the delivery could not have been made, that’s what you should be looking at!

The courier had a choice, they could have posted a note, I have a parcel, giving instructions for collection at a later date. 

The courier however, was to lazy and left the parcel on top the letter box, which is in a insecure area. Then claiming they posted the parcel through the letter box, this is want I am being penalised for!

It’ laughable!

Anyone reading this thread should be aware, the buyer on Grailed is treated poorly if anything goes wrong. Grailed and Paypal have received a percentage, the buyer received their money.

I am the only party not to have received my item or money back, this is Grailed response to me, by opening a dispute, I am “ financially penalising the buyer” just a bizarre use of words to describe the situation.

The advise they gave me was to contact the courier company, I did not buy the service, the seller is the only one could could do that.

They said contact the police, the police said I should contact the courier, so basically I have lost my money.

By opening the dispute with Paypal, I did not penalise the the seller, I was asking Paypal to investigate this matter.  But clearly you have know regard for my loss.

Anyone reading this thread, I would advise any buyer to be aware, if any problems occur with that delivery, Grailed and Paypal will disregard you.

If the courier claims to have delivered your item,
basically any conversation you have with these platforms is useless, they will just keep saying it was delivered.

So if the courier leaves the package with a neighbour, it’s been delivered. If the courier leaves the package outside your house is delivered. If it’s left on top of a letterbox, it’s been delivered!

By any logic, they clearly have not been delivered successfully, but the platforms hide behind this policy.

A reputable courier will come back if your not in, however many courier companies, especially in London, will ring other buzzers especially in flats,
until someone comes down.

If someone signs for that, according to Grailed and Paypal that’s a delivery. So depending on the honestly of that person, if you receive that parcel.

If you have just spent £800 on a jacket and that situation occurred, Grailed and Paypal will just say it was delivered!

I just thought you are the platform hosting the sale process, I just thought if any problem occurred you would help, clearly not. Very disappointing!

I have closed the case with Paypal, when will my account be unfrozen!

I am the only party to have lost financially, but the way I have been treated, you would have thought I had committed some heinous crime.

The crime being I have not received the item I paid for, just a utter disgrace!

author: Gary
text:
I recently had a experience with a courier, they claimed to have posted my parcel through my letterbox.

My letterbox is quite small, so how a parcel was put through it, I am still perplexed!

I can only assume the courier placed the parcel on top of the letterbox, then claims the parcel was posted through the letterbox.

Because the courier claimed it was posted through letterbox, according to Grailed that’s a signed for delivery, they will not intervene in this matter.

The parcel was not in the letterbox or on top, I can only assume it was stolen. 

The interesting point being, when I contacted Grailed about this, they said repeatedly if the tracking information says it was delivered,
they will not intervene.

The advice they gave, was to contact the courier or the police.

If the tracking information says it was delivered, no mistake could have happened in this process, according to Grailed.

When posting expensive items use a reputable courier, they are more likely to make a successful delivery.

Especially in London, couriers will ring numerous
flats buzzers if your not in and give the parcel to a neighbour or any person coming out.

If that happens, according to Grailed that’s a successful signed delivery.

Less reputable couriers have time restraints, so are likely to leave parcel in a insecure location 
or person.

In my experience, couriers like UPS and DHL offer more delivery options, if you are not in. More importantly, they will not leave parcel with insecure person or location.

In these situations the seller is covered, but the buyer is completely ignored. When sending your expensive items choose a reputable courier, so the buyer is more likely to receive the parcel.

If this situation happens to you, you can not make a claim. According to Grailed if you do, you are making a malicious claim against the seller and your account will be frozen.
title: Use reputable courier when shipping.
